By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
I am not very familiar with the mathematics, can you explain a little bit what is the point of the main theorem?

> I am not very familiar with the mathematics, can you explain a little bit what is the point of the main theorem?

There's a normal form (and reduced form) for words in the amalgamated product. The main application of this is that it implies the injectivity of the maps into the amalgamated product and the theorem `inf_of_range_eq_base_range`. 

Other than that, I don't directly know any applications, but the similar result about reduced forms for `HNNExtension`s is used to prove things like the decision procedure for groups presented by a single relation. 

So I suppose it's useful to know this reduced form theorem, because then you know a lot about which words are equal to each other, and which words are in the base subgroup and things like this, but I couldn't say anything more concrete.

> The maths look great, I would just be happy to see more documentation (featuring prominently the word "amalgamated product" here and there, because it's the name I know for these objects, not the categorical ones pushouts or coproducts, but I realize it's a question of personal taste or personal culture -- but it would be good to make sure that anyone with any culture can find this with a good old `grep`).

I chose the word pushout, because as far as I know, the phrase amalgamated product only refers to the case when all maps in the diagram are injective. This is basically the interesting case, but the construction works the rest of the time.

bors r+
Thanks!

Pull request successfully merged into master.

The maths look great, I would just be happy to see more documentation (featuring prominently the word "amalgamated product" here and there, because it's the name I know for these objects, not the categorical ones pushouts or coproducts, but I realize it's a question of personal taste or personal culture -- but it would be good to make sure that anyone with any culture can find this with a good old `grep`).
What about splitting the PR in two, where in the first one you only define the pushout and prove basic properties? In any case it looks like a great addition to mathlib, thanks!
What about splitting the PR in two, where in the first one you only define the pushout and prove basic properties? In any case it looks like a great addition to mathlib, thanks!

The maths look great, I would just be happy to see more documentation (featuring prominently the word "amalgamated product" here and there, because it's the name I know for these objects, not the categorical ones pushouts or coproducts, but I realize it's a question of personal taste or personal culture -- but it would be good to make sure that anyone with any culture can find this with a good old `grep`).
What about making `Ï†` explicit in `base`? It looks weird that it has zero explicit variables.
`Ï†` can also be explicit here.
On the other hand `f` and `k` can be implicit here (but it can make things uglier later on).
The goal `hf` will usually be filled in by `ext; simp` or some other tactic, so I think it's best to keep `f` and `k` explicit.
Is there a reason for the `1199`?
It's to keep the priority lower than `hom_ext_nonempty`, which has one less hypothesis to prove.

```suggestion
`w` itself is not in the image of the base group. -/
```

```suggestion
  ( injective : âˆ€ i, Injective (Ï† i) )
```

The docstring is not very informative by itself, since it refers to `Monoid.CoprodI.Pair`. Can you make it more self-contained so that it is useful when it appears in a tooltip? (But still mentioning `Monoid.CoprodI.Pair` for reference).

```suggestion
/-- Induction principle for `NormalWord`, that corresponds closely to inducting on
```

```suggestion
/-- Take the product of a normal word as an element of the `PushoutI`. We show that this is
bijective, in `NormalWord.equiv`. -/
```
Could you add a docstring to this theorem and the next theorem, that would mention both the words `pushout` and `amalgamated product`?

```suggestion
  classical
```
why not move the assumption left of the colon?
add a docstring?

I think it would be good to add a good chunk of documentation here, explaining what is true, what definitions you are going to introduce, and how you will prove that the normal form is indeed a normal form.

I am not very familiar with the mathematics, can you explain a little bit what is the point of the main theorem?

> I am not very familiar with the mathematics, can you explain a little bit what is the point of the main theorem?

There's a normal form (and reduced form) for words in the amalgamated product. The main application of this is that it implies the injectivity of the maps into the amalgamated product and the theorem `inf_of_range_eq_base_range`. 

Other than that, I don't directly know any applications, but the similar result about reduced forms for `HNNExtension`s is used to prove things like the decision procedure for groups presented by a single relation. 

So I suppose it's useful to know this reduced form theorem, because then you know a lot about which words are equal to each other, and which words are in the base subgroup and things like this, but I couldn't say anything more concrete.

The maths look great, I would just be happy to see more documentation (featuring prominently the word "amalgamated product" here and there, because it's the name I know for these objects, not the categorical ones pushouts or coproducts, but I realize it's a question of personal taste or personal culture -- but it would be good to make sure that anyone with any culture can find this with a good old `grep`).

> The maths look great, I would just be happy to see more documentation (featuring prominently the word "amalgamated product" here and there, because it's the name I know for these objects, not the categorical ones pushouts or coproducts, but I realize it's a question of personal taste or personal culture -- but it would be good to make sure that anyone with any culture can find this with a good old `grep`).

I chose the word pushout, because as far as I know, the phrase amalgamated product only refers to the case when all maps in the diagram are injective. This is basically the interesting case, but the construction works the rest of the time.

bors r+
Thanks!
